newsitem.title: HONG KONG: Japan stocks rebound, but gloom persists.
newsitem.headline: Japan stocks rebound, but gloom persists.

text.p: Japanese stocks recovered strongly on Monday in a rollercoaster session, clawing back some of the huge losses sustained last week and lifting other Asian markets.
After initially hitting an early low of 17,019.56, Japan's key Nikkei 225 index ended a hectic session up 815.14 points, or 4.71 percent, at 18,118.79 -- its first rally in a week.

Monday's sharp gain was more than enough to offset what the benchmark lost on Friday, when it suffered the biggest single-day drop in two years. It lost more than 2,000 points last week because of spreading gloom over the government's ability to keep the nation's economic recovery on track.
Analysts called the rebound "technical", however, and said the market was still gripped by worries about the economy and the health of some financial institutions.

The rally was also bolstered by a report that a senior official of Japan's ruling party had called for measures to deal with weak stock prices. But a top government official quickly denied that any bailout measures would be taken by the government.
Hong Kong stocks rose on solid gains in the banking sector, and pared losses in property counters, brokers said. The Hang Seng Index closed 97.71 points higher at 13,289.21.
Edwin Cheung, dealing director at Taiwan Securities, said buying was mainly focused on banking stocks as investors took action ahead of earnings announcements expected soon.

The surge in Tokyo also provided an afternoon lift. "Nobody needs a crisis in the region so the rebound in Japan is certainly helpful," said Kent Rossiter, institutional sales manager at Nikko Securities.
Stocks in Seoul ended Monday's trading at exactly Saturday's closing of 659.54 points as fears over strikes matched improving sentiment in financial stocks, brokers said.
South Korea faces its biggest strikes ever on Wednesday when the nation's two main union umbrella groups plan to call out an all-out strike in protest at a new labour law.
Brokers said many investors were optimistic that a last-minute solution, or at least some indication of an early settlement, to the stoppages could be reached.
Taiwan's main stock index closed higher for the third straight day, rising to a six-year high to end up 71.40 points, or one percent, at 7,189.47.
Brokers cited healthy rotational rises in construction shares, textiles, electrics, electronics and plastics.

The index has rebounded for six of the past seven sessions since taking a 1.64 percent plunge on January 4 after Taiwan provincial governor James Soong's shock resignation to protest moves to dismantle his largely redundant administration.
The political uncertainties have waned since President Lee Teng-hui met Soong last week, brokers said.
Thai stocks closed sharply lower in moderate trade as investors sold on concerns that the government faced difficulty implementing plans to assist the Thai property sector, analysts said.
The SET Index ended down 17.61 points, or 2.10 percent, to 822.89.
At 1145 GMT, the dollar was trading at 116.31/41 yen and 1.5842/47 marks, .
Gold fell slightly in Hong Kong in subdued trading. Bullion ended at US$358.50/359.00 against New York's $358.80/359.30 close on Friday.
Crude futures firmed, boosted by worries about cold weather in the U.S. northeast. February Brent climbed 16 cents to $24.50 per barrel from London trading on Friday. March rose 18 cents to $24.02.
